description: From Middle English mowen (participle mowen), from Old English māwan (past tense mēow, past participle māwen), from Proto-West Germanic *māan, from Proto-Germanic *mēaną, from Proto-Indo-European *h₂meh₁- (“to mow, reap”).

See also Dutch maaien, German mähen, Danish meje, Swedish meja; also Hittite [script needed] (ḫamešḫa, “spring/early summer”, literally “mowing time”), Latin metō (“I harvest, mow”), Ancient Greek ἀμάω (amáō, “I mow”).

entries.meaning: The act of mowing (a garden, grass, etc.).
examples: The lawn hasn't had a mow for a couple of months, so it's like a jungle out there!

entries.meaning: (cricket) A shot played with a sweeping or scythe-like motion.
examples: I consider it would engender a stiff, tame, cautious mode of play, with only now and then a mow, or a chopping hit.

verbs.description: mow (third-person singular simple present mows, present participle mowing, simple past mowed, past participle mowed or mown)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cut down grass or crops.
examples: He mowed the lawn every few weeks in the summer.

entries.meaning: (transitive, often with through) To cut down or slaughter in great numbers.
examples: In the afternoon they attacked again, in close formation: our artillery mowed them, but they came on and on,  […]

description: Middle English mowe, from Middle French moue (“lip, pout”), from Old French moe (“grimace”), from Frankish *mauwa (“pout, protruding lip”), from Proto-Germanic *mawwō (“muff, sleeve”). Akin to Middle Dutch mouwe (“protruding lip”). Cognate to moue (“pout”).

entries.meaning: (now only dialectal) A scornful grimace; a wry face. [from 14th c.]
examples: Those that paint them dying […] delineate the prisoners spitting in their executioners faces, and making mowes at them.

verbs.description: mow (third-person singular simple present mows, present participle mowing, simple past and past participle mowed)

description: Old English mūga. Cognate with Norwegian muge (“heap, crowd, flock”).

entries.meaning: (now regional) A stack of hay, corn, beans or a barn for the storage of hay, corn, beans.
The place in a barn where hay or grain in the sheaf is stowed.

verbs.description: mow (third-person singular simple present mows, present participle mowing, simple past and past participle mowed)
